author: By Alex Marshall

O’Connor was at the RTE Choice Music Prize, an evening celebrating the best Irish albums of the past year. description: The latest in a series of Julius Eastman recordings, a new opera by Christopher Cerrone and an EP from Ashley Bathgate are among the highlights.
content: This is the third in Wild Up’s series of recordings of works by Julius Eastman (1940-90), and it showcases the range of Eastman’s indelible naming style: witty (“If You’re So Smart, Why Aren’t You Rich?”); poetic (“The Moon’s Silent Modulation”); inflammatory (“Evil Nigger”). These are stormy, swiftly shifting, open-ended scores, rendered in new arrangements by Wild Up’s large and varied ensemble with passion, richness and complexity — a forest of details — and a controlled chaos inspired by free jazz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Locust Valley, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Wilton, Conn.
content: A five-bedroom, three-full-and-two-half-bath, 3,698-square-foot house built in 1964, with a wood-burning fireplace and bay window in the living room; built-ins, a fireplace and a wet bar in the den; an island, two dishwashers and skylights in the eat-in kitchen; a main-floor laundry room; and an attached two-car garage, on 1.36 acres. Kimberly Greene Bancroft, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-404-5053; danielgale.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Where to Drink Wine in Madrid
description: This warm, generous city overflows with great wine lists in restaurants and wine and tapas bars. Here are nine places you should try.
content: To many tourists, Madrid is kind of an afterthought, Spain’s second city after Barcelona, which, in their minds, abounds with youthful energy, quirky architecture, a thriving arts scene, beautiful beaches and superb restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Announces Steps to Help Communities Deal With Extreme Heat
description: The measures include protections for workers and funds for better weather prediction, but they are unlikely to satisfy activists who have pushed the president to do more to combat climate change.
content: President Biden directly linked recent record heat waves with climate change on Thursday and announced new measures aimed at helping communities endure extreme weather, as rising temperatures scorch much of the country and amplify alarms about global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Sinead O’Connor Condemned Church Abuse Early. America Didn’t Listen.
description: In Ireland, Ms. O’Connor spoke out about abuse and the complicity of religious institutions. When she came to the United States, many were not ready to hear her — yet.
content: Americans began to grapple with a nationwide epidemic of child abuse in Catholic parishes and other religious organizations in 2002, after a landmark Boston Globe investigation revealed a pattern of misdeeds and cover-ups in Boston that went back decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Trumpeter Stretches Past the Bounds of Jazz
description: Chief Xian aTunde Adjuah’s new album, “Bark Out Thunder Roar Out Lightning,” is his first on which he doesn’t touch the trumpet. Instead, he extends the legacy of Black masking Indians in New Orleans.
content: Growing up in New Orleans, Chief Xian aTunde Adjuah was raised at the corner of two traditions. He learned to play the trumpet at the elbow of his uncle and mentor, the saxophonist Donald Harrison Jr., whose career took off after a stint in Art Blakey’s band. Harrison was a true-blue jazz musician, and Adjuah — who was born, and first introduced to the listening public as, Christian Scott — seemed destined to become one, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Titanium Clouds Engulf This Ultrahot Neptune-like Planet
description: A cosmic mirror of sorts, this planet is the first of its size and location to be discovered with an atmosphere.
content: Astronomers have come across the shiniest planet ever found, a mere 265 light years from our solar system. But that’s hardly its only standout trait. Shrouded by thick metallic clouds, this world’s temperature reaches a blistering 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit, and it quite likely rains scorching-hot drops of titanium.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Mexican Craft Brewery Where You Can Spend the Night
description: Plus: an exhibition of Remedios Varo’s surrealist paintings, daybeds upholstered in classic textiles and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Seen from the outside, Red Jane, a new bakery in the center of Chania, a Greek port city on the island of Crete, looks like a Berlin nightclub, with no obvious sign and a concrete facade covered in graffiti. Inside, it might pass for a New York boutique: There are Italian tiles on the floor and an exposed-brick ceiling and on a long red marble counter, lit by minimalist pendant lamps, pastries are laid out like jewels in a glass vitrine. Owned by Nikos Tsepetis, the hotelier behind the nearby beach resort Ammos (a favorite of the art and design crowd), the space is the first fully realized interiors project overseen by the London-based lighting and furniture designer Michael Anastassiades. Eyal Schwartz, the former head baker and co-owner of London’s E5 Bakehouse, created the menu. On its opening day this month, Red Jane sold out of its chocolate-filled croissants, koulouri (Greek sesame-topped bagels) and baklava swirls by noon. Locals lingered for an hour after, despite the fact that Tsepetis and Anastassiades designed the space without tables. redjaneproject.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Beasts’ Review: Bad Neighbors
description: Class tensions and masculine power games abound in this engrossing rural thriller from Spain.
content: “The Beasts,” an engrossing rural thriller by the Spanish director Rodrigo Sorogoyen, has a deeper take on the class tensions of most hill-people horror movies. Antoine (Denis Mé nochet) and Olga (Marina Foïs), a middle-class French couple, have recently settled in the Galician village of Ourense, where they run a modest farm and spend their surplus of free time rebuilding dilapidated homes. Their neighbors, Xan (Luis Zahera) and Lorenzo (Diego Anido), a tetchy pair of middle-aged brothers, despise them. A Swedish wind-turbine company has offered to pay out the village’s residents should they approve the installment of an energy farm on the land — by voting “no,” Antoine and Olga deny the impoverished brothers what for them would be a considerable sum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Bronny James, Recovering From Cardiac Arrest, Goes Home From the Hospital
description: LeBron James Jr.’s release was one of several indications that things were returning to normal three days after he collapsed on a basketball court.
content: Three days after LeBron James Jr. collapsed during a basketball practice, a cardiologist at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles said on Thursday that he “has been discharged home, where he is resting.” His father, LeBron James, said on social media that his family was “together, safe and healthy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Alvin Ailey Celebrates Its 65th Season With Tribute to Ailey Women
description: The winter season at City Center features premieres by Amy Hall Garner and Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish, and a program honoring women who shaped the organization.
content: Revivals of works by Ronald K. Brown and Jamar Roberts and world premieres by Amy Hall Garner and Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish will come to the City Center stage for Alvin Ailey Dance Company’s winter season, the company announced Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Clover and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: My Life in the New Millennium
description: Joshua Clover begins with hating people and loving cats, quickly adding juxtapositions and surprises.
content: Joshua Clover’s “My Life in the New Millennium” begins with a thorny, if familiar, either/or. Then the poem moves quickly to accrue its juxtapositions and surprises, providing room for both Whitney Houston and the world system, for both wit and committed seriousness, for gravity and light. By the end of the poem, its initial dilemma has found a resolution: a shared category, capacious enough for both people and cats — and for history itself. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You a Legacy Alum?
description: We’d like to hear what you think about colleges giving admissions preference to relatives of alumni.
content: After the Supreme Court’s rejection of affirmative action at American colleges and universities, another admissions practice has come under scrutiny: preferences for relatives of alumni. Known as legacy admissions, the practice tends to favor wealthy white applicants over others, including Black, Hispanic, Asian American and Native American students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 7 Fashion: Aidan’s Return
description: Carrie’s other great love reappears just in time for Valentine’s Day.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 7 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell Reports Sharply Lower Earnings as Energy Prices Ease
description: After a record-breaking profit last year, Shell’s quarterly earnings fell 56 percent. But the energy provider will increase dividend payments.
content: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, said Thursday that its profit fell 56 percent in the second quarter from record-breaking earnings of a year earlier, to $5.07 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Check out the return of a savvy comedy and a strangely moving and beautiful true crime series.
content: ‘This Fool’When to watch: Friday, on Hulu.

author: By David Broder
title: What’s Happening in Italy Is Scary, and It’s Spreading
description: In galvanizing the political right behind resentful identity politics, Giorgia Meloni is leading the way.
content: ROME — What a difference a few months can make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Bobi Wine: The People’s President’ Review: A Pop Star Turns Politician
description: Uganda has been under authoritarian rule for decades. Wine has doggedly challenged its leader, and this documentary shows the price he’s paid.
content: The pop-culture personage turned politician is not so novel a figure as it used to be. But the Ugandan pop singer Robert Kyagulanyi Ssentamu, who goes by the stage name Bobi Wine, has earned, by way of his courage and resilience, the special consideration this documentary affords him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘North Circular’ Review: A Musical Tour Through Dublin
description: In this black-and-white documentary by Luke McManus, the camera finds stories and songs near a road north of the city’s center.
content: The discursive documentary “North Circular” takes viewers on a tour of the history, music and geography of Dublin. The title refers to North Circular Road, which forms an arc that passes north of the city’s center, and that offers a loose map for the film’s themes. Directed by Luke McManus and shot in a ghostly black-and-white, “North Circular” finds stories and songs near the thoroughfare’s path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: How Does a Prolific Author Deal With Cold Feet?
description: Riley Sager has been on a publishing tear since 2017. His seventh book, “The Only One Left,” almost interfered with his breakneck pace.
content: In the past six years, Riley Sager has published seven novels — all of them best sellers except his first, “Final Girls,” which won a 2018 International Thriller Writers Award. The Pennsylvania native reliably produces one book a year on a strict schedule that sounded remarkably uncomplicated (if dizzying) when he described it in a phone interview.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tara Westover Likes to Read Herself to Sleep, When She Can
description: “My thinking is that reading will focus my mind, bring a hush over the chaos of the day so I can drift off,” says the author of the memoir “Educated,” one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2018. “But from time to time a book takes hold in that peculiar way that a book can, and I end up reading through the night. ... Books are both the best and worst thing for my sleep.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Erin Nolan and Judson Jones
title: Spared the Worst of Summer Until Now, the Northeast Joins a Nation Scorched
description: The heat index reached the triple digits across the nation’s most populous region, and could peak on Friday. Many cities took precautions to help vulnerable residents.
content: New York City’s power company asked customers to cut back on electricity use Thursday afternoon, and Philadelphia declared a health emergency as the dangerous heat that has scorched other parts of the country for more than a month spread to the nation’s most populous region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Jeffrey Gibson, Indigenous U.S. Artist, Is Selected for Venice Biennale
description: The multimedia artist is known for incorporating a Native American perspective into legacies of modernism and craft that define today’s cultural foundations.
content: Jeffrey Gibson, a multimedia artist who challenges the absence of Native American practices in visual culture, will represent the United States at the next edition of the Venice Biennale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: A Jets Star Emerges, and Helps to Pull in Another
description: Garrett Wilson broke out in his rookie season as the dynamic receiver the Jets have long lacked. Now he’s reminding Aaron Rodgers of a productive partnership from the past.
content: The diner resembled so many others peppering New Jersey. Garrett Wilson held high expectations as he climbed from an idling S.U.V. This was Sopranos country, after all, where bottomless menus and bustling service await every eager lunchtime patron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: This Looks Like Earth’s Warmest Month. Hotter Ones Appear to Be in Store.
description: July is on track to break all records for any month, scientists say, as the planet enters an extended period of exceptional warmth.
content: Weeks of scorching summer heat in North America, Europe, Asia and elsewhere are putting July on track to be Earth’s warmest month on record, the European Union climate monitor said on Thursday, the latest milestone in what is emerging as an extraordinary year for global temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: The Tiny Irish Village Where Sinéad O’Connor Escaped the World
description: For three years, the singer, who died this week, found simplicity and happiness in a mountain sanctuary where she was just another neighbor.
content: Few people come to Knockananna without good reason, the journey requiring a long, serpentine drive up the country roads that wind through Ireland’s Wicklow Mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford’s Profit Jumped in Second Quarter
description: The automaker made more money on trucks and sport utility vehicles but reported bigger losses on electric vehicles.
content: Ford Motor earned $1.9 billion from April to June, up from $667 million a year earlier, the company said on Thursday. Robust sales of gasoline-powered trucks and sport-utility vehicles more than offset a substantial loss on electric models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Citigroup Says Its Predecessors Likely Benefited From Slavery
description: The bank’s latest historical review, done as part of its racial equity pledge, shows indirect ties rather than direct profits.
content: A new review of historical documents has led Citigroup to acknowledge that slavery and slave labor most likely enriched the banks and other companies that eventually formed the present-day financial giant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 27, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 27, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about the scaling back of technology companies in New York misstated the scope of layoffs by large technology companies since early 2022. They have laid off more than 386,000 workers worldwide, not just in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Try Tolerance in a Small Town
description: The true measure of a community lies not in how it treats insiders but in how it treats outsiders.
content: It’s been a long time since I cared about a country song. Perhaps that’s because when I heard Zac Brown Band’s “Colder Weather” back in 2010, I thought that country music would never, ever achieve such greatness again, so I tuned it out. (I was never much of a country fan in the first place.) But just when I thought I was out, country music pulled me back in — alas, this time for culture-war reasons. The latest angry new controversy centers on a country song, Jason Aldean’s “Try That in a Small Town.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A Half-Million Americans May Have Tick-Linked Meat Allergy, C.D.C. Says
description: Many doctors said that they were unfamiliar with the condition, known as alpha-gal syndrome, the agency found.
content: As many as 450,000 Americans may be living with alpha-gal syndrome, a meat allergy that has been linked to tick bites, with many of those people going undiagnosed, according to two new studies from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Bew
title: On Ibiza, a Celebration of Summer Love
description: Adam Shapiro and Gautam Rajani, the founders of the clothing brand SMR Days, invited friends and family back to the Spanish island where they got married to toast their first anniversary.
content: Prevailing wisdom holds that mixing business and romance is a bad idea. For Adam Shapiro and Gautam Rajani, the opposite has been true. The London-based couple — partners in life and in work — recently celebrated both their first wedding anniversary and the debut of their resort-inspired men’s wear label, SMR Days, at London Fashion Week. This past May, to mark the milestones, they invited 27 guests to an outdoor dinner in Ibiza, Spain, where they’d hosted their three-day wedding last summer. “This place has played a major role in what we do,” says Shapiro of the Balearic island. “We’ve gone every summer since we got together in 2017, sometimes for 10 days, sometimes for two months, and we’ve built an amazing friend circle on the island.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Carl Hulse
title: As McConnell Tries to Convey Business as Usual, His Future Is in Doubt
description: The minority leader’s health episode at the Capitol has intensified talk about a possible succession, a prospect that his colleagues have not seriously grappled with for years.
content: It has been decades since there was any real uncertainty at the top of the Republican Party in the Senate. But Senator Mitch McConnell’s alarming freeze-up at a news conference on Wednesday at the Capitol, as well as new disclosures about other recent falls, have shaken his colleagues and intensified quiet discussion about how long he can stay in his position as minority leader, and whether change is coming at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Haunted Mansion’ Review: A Disney Ride to Nowhere Fun
description: Starring LaKeith Stanfield and Rosario Dawson, this movie plays like a feature-length ad for Disney’s theme-park attraction of the same name.
content: There is a mansion, it is haunted, boo, blah, the end.

description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 27, 2023.

title: An American Energy Giant Sees Israel as a Springboard to Europe
description: Chevron finds itself with an abundance of natural gas on Europe’s doorstep. Amid competing regional interests, the question is how to develop it.
content: Six miles off the coast of Israel, beyond the brightly colored sails of wind surfers, an ungainly steel structure looms above the blue Mediterranean.

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Don’t Take Zucchini for Granted
description: Summer’s ubiquitous squash shines when raw, sliced and smashed into panzanella and salads.
content: Like many, I took in Greta Gerwig’s fluorescent “Barbie” this past weekend. No moment of the surreal film has stuck with me quite like the use of “Push,” the angsty, alt-rock ’90s hit from the band Matchbox Twenty.

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Beyond the City, Summertime Theater That’s Worth the Drive
description: A guide to what’s onstage at theater festivals in upstate New York and the Berkshires.
content: In summertime, a lot of stage talent heads for the Hudson River Valley and western Massachusetts, where curious audiences follow. Here is some of what theaters there have on tap this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Record Heat Hits the Northeast
description: Also, Ukraine seeks a breakthrough in the south. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: As dangerous heat spread to the most populous region in the U.S. today, spiking temperatures and a blanket of oppressive humidity prompted heat warnings in New England and the Mid-Atlantic states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: What Russia Sees: In Crimea, ‘Everyone Is Having Fun’
description: Since Russia invaded Ukraine last year, Russian government officials and state television have hammered home the message that everything is fine.
content: On Russian state television, explosions on the roadway of a 12-mile bridge are no reason to cancel your vacation to the beaches of the Crimean Peninsula, even with a war raging nearby on mainland Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Economy Grew at 2.4% Rate in Second Quarter
description: The reading on gross domestic product was bolstered by consumer spending, showing that recession forecasts early in the year were premature, at least.
content: The economic recovery gained momentum in the spring as buoyant consumer spending and resurgent business investment helped, once again, to keep a recession at bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder, Abbie VanSickle and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: How Supreme Court Justices Make Millions From Book Deals
description: The deals have become highly lucrative for the justices, including for those who used court staff members to help research and promote their books.
content: Only three months into Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson’s first Supreme Court term, she announced a book deal negotiated by the same powerhouse lawyer who represented the Obamas and James Patterson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Young Bros and Maidens Harmonize in ‘Love’s Labor’s Lost’
description: This peculiar early Shakespeare comedy gets updated with 10 songs for a youthful alfresco production.
content: “Let’s rock!” is something I’m pretty sure no character in Shakespeare ever said. But on a sandy stage under a jaunty tent, with a green hillside as a welcoming backdrop, it seemed an apt way to begin “Love’s Labor’s Lost.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Amid Shared Pain Over Synagogue Massacre, Divisions on Death Penalty
description: Since the 2018 attack that left 11 people dead, Jews in Pittsburgh have weighed whether the government should seek the execution of the killer.
content: Nearly a year after 11 people were murdered in the Pittsburgh synagogue where he worshiped, Stephen Cohen wrote a letter to the U.S. attorney general. The Justice Department had not yet declared its intent to seek a death sentence in the case, and Mr. Cohen, the co-president of New Light, one of the three congregations that met in the Tree of Life synagogue, wanted to weigh in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Black History Is a Casualty in Ron DeSantis’s Christian Nationalist Quest
description: Florida’s distortion of the history of slavery is more consequential than many comprehend.
content: Last week, Florida approved an overhaul of its African American history standards, including guidance that middle schoolers should be instructed that “slaves developed skills which, in some instances, could be applied for their personal benefit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Bars for Checking People Out
description: Guilherme Gilioli adds another New York Times Crossword to his body of work.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wyatt Mason
title: The Kidnapped Child Who Became a Poet
description: At age 3, Shane McCrae was taken from his Black father by his white grandparents — a rupture he explores in a new memoir.
content: “The weird thing about growing up kidnapped,” Shane McCrae, the 47-year-old American poet, told me in his melodious, reedy voice one rainy afternoon in May, “is if it happens early enough, there’s a way in which you kind of don’t know.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Talk to Me’ Review: Letting the Wrong One In
description: A bereaved young woman falls under the spell of a dangerous artifact in this vibrant and poignant horror debut.
content: Steeped in yearning and chockablock with shocks, “Talk to Me,” the first feature from the Australian filmmaking brothers Danny Philippou and Michael Philippou, is a horror movie huddled tightly around a story of filial grief. The result is an enduring melancholy that no amount of ghouls or gore can entirely dispel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘El Agua’ Review: After the Flood, the Legends
description: This film from Elena López Riera follows what happens when floods drench a village in southeastern Spain.
content: In the southeastern Spanish village where the director Elena López Riera grew up — and where her debut feature, “El Agua,” is set — water is both a boon and a curse. This dry region doesn’t get enough rain for its lemon and orange crops, but when it does pour, there are frequently devastating floods. And as is often the case with forces we cannot control or understand, it’s the village’s women who are blamed for nature’s caprices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: If You Can’t Stand the Heat … We’ve Got Some Suggestions
description: A little advice for August: Structure your days around beating the heat. Or, if you’re tempted by one of these outdoor events, stay hydrated.
content: As fireworks danced across the sky on the Fourth of July, the Earth heated up at record levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Biden and Meloni May Find Common Ground at White House
description: The president has been wary of the Italian prime minister’s hard-right politics. But when they meet on Thursday, they may see eye to eye on key issues.
content: Not long ago, Giorgia Meloni rose in Italian politics campaigning against migrants and the European Union while seeking alliances with supporters of Donald J. Trump. Now prime minister of Italy, she would seem to have little in common with President Biden, who once compared the hard-right philosophy she shared with Mr. Trump to “semi-fascism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: How to Stay Cool in New York City During Extreme Heat
description: Officials are encouraging residents to take advantage of cooling centers and splash pads. They are also warning against operating air conditioning at maximum capacity.
content: Officials are urging New Yorkers to find safe and reliable ways to stay cool over the next few days while the city is expected to face dangerously high temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Where Wildfires Are Raging in Europe and North Africa
description: Firefighters have scrambled to extinguish blazes in at least 10 countries as a heat wave has swept the Mediterranean region. Here’s what to know.
content: Hundreds of wildfires have burned their way through Southern Europe and North Africa this week, with residents of nearby communities forced to flee the billowing smoke and advancing blazes. Firefighters in at least 10 countries in the region have mobilized firefighting planes and trucks to douse the blazes, which have blackened thousands of acres of land, consumed buildings and killed dozens of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bill Geddie, a Creator of ‘The View,’ Is Dead at 68
description: His partnership with Barbara Walters began when he produced her prime-time specials. He later helped turn her idea for an all-female talk show into a long-running hit.
content: Bill Geddie, whose long working relationship with the barrier-breaking television newswoman Barbara Walters began when he produced her prime-time specials on ABC, then expanded when he collaborated with her on “The View,” one of TV’s most successful daytime talk shows, died on July 20 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Finally, a Memorial to the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire’s Victims
description: Steel panels will bear the names of the 146 workers, most of them women, who died in the 1911 blaze. Also, a “pay to play” Long Island restaurateur is sentenced to prison.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at plans for a memorial to one of the city’s worst tragedies, a deadly fire that led to changes in the workplace. We’ll also find out how much time a restaurateur who paid off politicians is going to spend in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Happiness for Beginners’ Review: Live, Laugh, Hike
description: Ellie Kemper and Luke Grimes star in “Happiness for Beginners,” an outdoorsy rom-com that’s inoffensive to a fault.
content: In Happiness for Beginners,” directed by Vicky Wight, the “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt” star Ellie Kemper portrays a divorced 30-something, Helen, on a journey of self-discovery and romance. Wight’s second adaptation of a novel by Katherine Center (after the 2020 drama “The Lost Husband”), the movie trades in warm-and-fuzzy predictability, where the most uprooting event imaginable for Kemper’s character is falling in love with her brother’s best friend, Jake (Luke Grimes), on a group hiking excursion along the Appalachian Trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk’s Quixotic Quest to Turn X Into an ‘Everything App’
description: Mr. Musk, the owner of Twitter, is the latest Silicon Valley mogul to pursue an all-in-one app, the kind that has thrived in Asia but not elsewhere.
content: Four years ago, a billionaire tech executive leading one of the world’s pre-eminent social platforms laid out a vision to transform it into an app that could do it all. In an online manifesto, he wrote that the app would not only be central to written communications but have audio, video, payments, commerce and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Ukraine begins the “big test” of its counteroffensive
content: Thousands of reinforcements poured into the two-month battle in the nation’s southeast, many of them trained and equipped by the West and, until now, held in reserve. “This is the big test,” one senior U.S. official said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Justices Ignoring the ‘Scent of Impropriety’
description: Readers respond to a judge’s guest essay. Also: The Trump inquiry costs; Rudy Giuliani; legacy admissions; Joe Biden’s dog; a Briton’s struggles.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Kokomo City’ Review: Dispatches From the Down Low
description: The director D. Smith’s new documentary follows four Black transgender women, who talk about how they got into sex work.
content: The documentary “Kokomo City” features interviews with people who aren’t often given the chance to publicly share their life stories. The film follows four Black transgender women, who speak directly to the camera about how they got into sex work and what they learned about human nature once they got there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Dreier
title: Labor Department Denounces Surge in Exploited Migrant Children
description: The agency said it had found thousands of cases where minors were employed in illegal, often dangerous jobs. Congress has accused the health secretary of failing to protect them.
content: The Labor Department on Thursday denounced a national surge in child labor, saying the agency’s inspectors had found thousands of violations and were investigating a slaughterhouse where a 16-year-old boy from Guatemala was killed this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley
title: Life Under U.K. Sanctions: Chauffeurs, Chefs and $1 Million Allowances
description: Despite tough talk, Britain’s new sanctions program against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has proved shaky. Some oligarchs have received generous exemptions. Officials have at times overreached.
content: The British government has allowed Russian oligarchs to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on perks like private chefs, chauffeurs and housekeepers, despite ostensibly having their bank accounts frozen, documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Has Scott Joplin’s ‘Thoroughly American Opera’ Found Its Moment?
description: “Treemonisha” — brilliant, flawed and unfinished — is ripe for creative reimagining at a time when opera houses are looking to diversify the canon.
content: “He has created an entirely new phase of musical art and has produced a thoroughly American opera.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: DeSantis Debuts a Leaner Campaign. But Donors Have Their Doubts.
description: As the Florida governor reboots in Iowa, tensions still plague the highest levels of his operation and a supportive super PAC.
content: On the day his presidential campaign said it had laid off more than a third of its staff to address worries about unsustainable spending, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida began his morning by boarding a private jet to Chattanooga, Tenn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: The Looming Crisis in the Bridal Industry? Not Enough Seamstresses.
description: The skilled professionals who work on wedding dress alterations play a crucial role for brides, but their numbers are dwindling.
content: On a video call in mid-June, a dozen women from across the country — many of them seated at sewing machines and enveloped by clouds of white tulle — debated the pros and cons of working in the busy world of bridal alterations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Clears the Way for Pipeline as Appeal Moves Forward
description: A congressional measure on the Mountain Valley Pipeline, championed by Senator Joe Manchin and added to legislation to raise the debt limit, was intended to thwart legal challenges to the project.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily cleared the way for construction of a 300-mile pipeline capable of carrying two billion cubic feet of natural gas daily from northern West Virginia to southern Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Warren and Graham Team Up to Take on Big Tech
description: The senators have forged a bipartisan alliance to create a new federal agency to police the power of tech giants like Amazon, Apple and Meta.
content: For years, policymakers have worried about the growing power of digital giants like Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta and Microsoft, as they came to dominate more and more of everyday life. Now, two prominent senators are pushing to create a new federal agency to rein in the power of Big Tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Susie Searches’ Review: The Sleuth Is Out There
description: Kiersey Clemons plays an amateur detective with a true-crime podcast and a secret in this quirky mystery movie.
content: Cinematic plays on the true-crime podcast craze are about as fresh as warmed-over veggie patties, yet “Susie Searches,” the debut feature film from Sophie Kargman, uses the trend to launch a satisfying if familiar mystery movie. Susie (Kiersey Clemons) is a college overachiever who in her spare time works at a burger joint, volunteers at the sheriff’s office and hosts a podcast investigating cold cases. This vast extracurricular catalog populates the story with an array of oddballs who, soon enough, make for a quirky cast of suspects when Jesse (Alex Wolff), a New Age influencer and campus celebrity, goes missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: What Happened When 15 of Twitter’s Top Celebrities Joined Threads
description: We examined the daily activity of Ellen DeGeneres, Wiz Khalifa, Selena Gomez and others among Twitter’s most-followed to deduce if Threads has staying power.
content: Threads, the new social app from Meta, had a fast start this month when it racked up 100 million downloads in less than a week. With so much momentum, the app seemed well on its way to dethroning Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: At Soho Rep, Eric Ting and Caleb Hammons to Join Leadership Team
description: Following the departures of Sarah Benson and Meropi Peponides, the two will join Cynthia Flowers as the company continues its shared leadership model.
content: Eric Ting and Caleb Hammons will join Cynthia Flowers as the next directors of Soho Rep, the Lower Manhattan theater announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in Murray Hill and South Park Slope.
content: A 585-square-foot condo that has a kitchen with granite countertops and a dishwasher, a limestone and marble bathroom, a sleeping alcove, and a washer/dryer, on the third floor of the Heritage at Trump Place, a 31-story doorman building from 2005 with a concierge, security team, children’s room, screening room, interior courtyard, valet parking garage, and a 15,000-square-foot gym and spa with several pools. Andy Kim, Olesia Goncharova and Cornell Jones, Nest Seekers International, 718-288-8022; nestseekers.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: European Central Bank Lays the Ground for a Rate Increase or a Pause
description: “We have an open mind,” the bank’s president said after raising interest rates for a ninth consecutive time.
content: For the past year, the European Central Bank has raised interest rates at every one of its policy meetings in an effort to rein in high inflation. Looking forward, that can no longer be the expectation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Volkswagen Seeks to Regain Edge in China as It Cuts Delivery Forecast
description: The German automaker lowered its outlook for deliveries and announced changes to its China strategy as it struggles to regain ground lost to other automakers.
content: Volkswagen, Europe’s largest automaker, is scaling back its forecast for deliveries in 2023 as it grapples with lagging sales of its electric vehicles, but the company said on Thursday that it hoped to bolster its position in China through increased collaboration with local technology companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: How Aimé Leon Dore Took New York
description: The brand, which bridges the streetwear-luxury gap and has taken on investment from LVMH, is a template for the future of men’s wear.
content: On the May evening before Aimé Leon Dore was set to make its grand return to Mulberry Street following eight months of construction on an extravagant new storefront, Teddy Santis, the brand’s founder, was walking around the shop floor, sweating the details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Four Decades Later, a Victim of the Highway Killer Is Finally Identified
description: Four bodies were found on an Indiana farm in 1983. The remains of Keith Lavell Bibbs, 16, of Chicago, were the last to be identified. All were victims of the serial killer Larry Eyler.
content: For nearly 40 years, the remains of a body found on an abandoned farm in rural Indiana were known as those of Adam Doe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sal Cataldi
title: The Roller Rink Popcorn Factory and the Jailhouse Pub
description: A look at the endless reinvention of the forgotten old buildings of the Hudson Valley.
content: When the owners of a solar-powered popcorn company in the Hudson Valley were looking to expand operations, they saw an opportunity in an empty roller rink. A former magazine editor who dreamed of opening an antiques store in the Catskills knew she’d found the perfect place when she came upon an 1870s firehouse. And about 20 miles away, a film producer turned liquor entrepreneur realized he could make and sell his products out of a retro drive-in movie theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: A Requiem for Diet Soda
description: The story of this beverage is the story of us.
content: Back in high school, I often woke before my parents did, and I could tell when my mother was about to get out of bed. A sound alerted me. I don’t mean an alarm clock. I mean the crunch-woosh of a can of diet soda being opened. Mom kept one on her night stand. That way, she could have her first sip the very moment her day began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Vows Support for Moscow in Visit by Russian Delegation
description: Pyongyang vowed increased military cooperation against the United States, a common enemy, during a visit by Russia’s defense minister.
content: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, vowed to expand military cooperation with Moscow in its confrontation with the United States as the Russian defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, led a delegation to Pyongyang, the North Korean state news media reported on Thursday.​
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily LaBarge
title: A Strange, but Elegant, Artistic Match
description: On the surface, Piet Mondrian and Hilma af Klint made very different work. But an exhibition at Tate Modern explores the pair’s shared obsessions, including astrology, X-rays and atoms.
content: In the middle of the exhibition “Hilma af Klint and Piet Mondrian: Forms of Life,” currently showing at Tate Modern, in London, sits a pair of maquettes that encapsulate the artists’ differences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen: The Vanishing Family, The Retrievals, Oppenheimer
description: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
content: Audiophiles,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: After Ousting a Top Official, China Erases Him and Evades Questions
description: China blasted “malicious hype” around the abrupt removal of Qin Gang. The Foreign Ministry’s fumbling response pointed to its diminished influence under Xi Jinping.
content: China’s abrupt removal of Qin Gang as foreign minister did not stop the questions that had dogged Chinese officials in the month since he vanished from public view: Where is Mr. Qin? Does he have health issues? Is he under investigation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: With a Temporary Contract Fix, Saquon Barkley and the Giants Get Back to Business
description: Barkley, the Giants running back, attended training camp after a last-minute, one-year deal ended talk that he would sit out. He and the team’s rush-heavy offense are still figuring out how much they need one another.
content: As Saquon Barkley, the Giants star running back, jogged from the huddle during a team drill Wednesday at a training camp practices, the couple hundred fans in attendance chanted his name in rhythmic cadence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Singleton
title: How Clever Tech Can Keep You Safe Outdoors
description: These apps and devices allow you to find your way, triage an injury and generally stay out of trouble on the trail.
content: Ten years ago, it wasn’t hard to get lost on a hike: read the map wrong and you could wander too far into the woods or down the wrong trail. But over the last few years, digital tools like trackers and apps have made exploring the outdoors safer and more accessible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh, Elian Peltier and Eric Schmitt
title: Held Hostage by His Military, Niger’s President Vows to Save Democracy
description: The army chief declared his support for a group of mutineers that seized power on Wednesday. President Mohamed Bazoum and his allies insisted the coup could be reversed.
content: Hours after soldiers seized power in the West African nation of Niger, the country’s ousted president sounded a defiant note on Thursday morning, vowing to protect his “hard won” democratic gains, even as he was being held hostage in the presidential palace by his own guards.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Brian Dillon’s essay collection “Affinities” is nominally a book of art criticism — most of the essays take visual artists as their starting point, and the book is subtitled “On Art and Fascination” — but its real charm (for this reader, anyway) is in the “fascination” part of that equation, as Dillon meditates on the various ways an image or story or striking detail can come to exert a hold on our imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Aatish Bhatia
title: How Big Is the Legacy Boost at Elite Colleges?
description: In the same week as a civil rights inquiry into Harvard, new data shows legacies are slightly more qualified yet are four times as likely to get into top schools.
content: The Education Department’s civil rights investigation into Harvard’s preference for admitting the children of alumni and donors is based on a complaint that it gives less-qualified applicants an edge over those who are more deserving, including students of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: What’s a Plant-Based Diet? Here’s What You Need to Know to Eat Less Meat.
description: It’s not the same as going vegan, but it can also have a strong impact on reducing your carbon footprint.
content: One thing much of the country seems to agree on is eating more plants. More than half of Americans (63 percent, regardless of political affiliation, according to a 2021 study by the Yale Program on Climate Change Communication) are actively trying to eat less red meat. In the United States, plant-based products grew into an $8 billion industry in 2022, with a growth rate of 7 percent since the year before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Michigan Judge Weighs Whether School Shooter Could Ever Leave Prison
description: A Supreme Court ruling from 2012 requires judges to consider eventual release for young defendants. A state judge must decide what that means for the shooter who killed four students at a Michigan high school.
content: If the teenager who killed four students at his Michigan high school and pleaded guilty to first-degree murder had been a few years older, there would be no question: He would be going to prison for the rest of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: A Less Anxious Edvard Munch
description: Beyond “The Scream,” there’s a side of the artist that’s long been unexplored in the U.S., as shown by “Trembling Earth” at the Clark Art Institute.
content: The exhibition of the work of the Norwegian painter and printmaker Edvard Munch at the Clark Art Institute here is fun. Serious fun. High fun, if you will. But fun nonetheless. The thrilling kind that comes from seeing a major modern painter in a new, broader, enlivening light. This is the achievement of the Clark’s sumptuous, revisionary “Edvard Munch: Trembling Earth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Flash of Anger Led to a Moment of Brilliance for U.S.
description: Lindsey Horan’s tying goal against the Netherlands saved her team at the World Cup. But it came from a dark place she knows well.
content: Lindsey Horan was still curled up on the field when she decided, enough already.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bongani Kona
title: A South African Biographer Brings Winnie and Nelson Back to Earth
description: Jonny Steinberg tells the story of Nelson Mandela and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela at a moment when a new generation is reassessing their legacies.
content: The South African leader and anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela died in 2013, suffering from dementia. We can only guess at the memories that whirled around his mind as he passed from one world to the next, but we know that at some point in his final hours he began calling for his ex-wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coco Romack
title: Artist-Designed Party Hats, and How to Recreate Them
description: Seven makers from across the creative fields propose fantastical celebratory headwear.
content: In the United States, party hats — those ubiquitous, cone-shaped signifiers of children’s birthdays and summer picnics — have their roots in a less celebratory phenomenon: the pointed dunce caps used as disciplinary tools in schools throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries. It’s a reminder that even the most unassuming objects can have complex meanings — something that artists, several of whom have turned to party attire for inspiration, have long known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook’s Algorithm Is ‘Influential’ but Doesn’t Necessarily Change Beliefs, Researchers Say
description: In four new studies, researchers found complicated results from experiments on Facebook’s and Instagram’s algorithms, suggesting there was no silver bullet to fixing the platforms.
content: The algorithms powering Facebook and Instagram, which drive what billions of people see on the social networks, have been in the cross hairs of lawmakers, activists and regulators for years. Many have called for the algorithms to be abolished to stem the spread of viral misinformation and to prevent the inflammation of political divisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Split Subway Series Leaves Both Teams Shrugging
description: It may be too late to save the Mets season, and the Yankees are not a sure bet for the postseason even once Aaron Judge returns.
content: The final installment of the 2023 subway series — lowercase, alas — began with a nifty bit of symmetry on Wednesday night in the Bronx. Brandon Nimmo, the Mets’ $162 million center fielder, faced Carlos Rodón, the Yankees’ $162 million left-hander. They fought to a draw — a full count, then a foul — before Nimmo struck out on high heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Julian Barry, Who Made Lenny Bruce Into ‘Lenny,’ Dies at 92
description: Mr. Barry’s scripts for a hit Broadway play and later a Hollywood movie about that rule-breaking comic helped give Mr. Bruce a lasting place in pop culture lore.
content: Julian Barry, whose scripts for a Broadway play and a Hollywood movie about Lenny Bruce, both titled “Lenny,” became definitive portraits of the comedian as a truth teller who drove himself mad in a righteous struggle against American hypocrisy, was found dead on Tuesday morning at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Damaged Tracks Caused Train Derailment That Killed 3, Investigators Say
description: An Amtrak derailment near Joplin, Mont., that also injured dozens was caused by poorly-maintained tracks that should have been inspected and replaced, the National Transportation Safety Board​ said.
content: Worn and poorly-maintained train tracks that should have been replaced caused the 2021 derailment of an Amtrak train in Montana that killed three people and injured 49 others, federal investigators said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Jobs Sit Empty in the Public Sector, So Unions Pitch In to Recruit
description: Shortages of state and city personnel, especially those who must work on site, are so dire that unions are helping to get people in the door.
content: The State of Minnesota, like nearly every public-sector employer across the country, is in a hiring crunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Judge Orders Release of Three of ‘Newburgh Four,’ Criticizing F.B.I.
description: Judge Colleen McMahon of U.S. District Court suggested that the federal agency had “invented” a conspiracy.
content: A federal judge on Thursday ordered the “compassionate release” of three Hudson Valley men who were part of a group known as the “Newburgh Four” after finding that F.B.I. agents had used an “unscrupulous operative” to persuade them to join a plot to blow up synagogues and bring down military planes more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Graham and Elizabeth Warren
title: Lindsey Graham and Elizabeth Warren: When It Comes to Big Tech, Enough Is Enough
description: We need a nimble, adaptable new agency with the expertise, resources and authority to rein in the tech giants that control our digital lives.
content: The digital revolution promised amazing new opportunities — and it delivered. Digital platforms promoted social interaction, democratized information and gave us hundreds of new ways to have fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert and Gaya Gupta
title: Prominent Horse Trainer Sentenced to 4 Years in Prison in Doping Scheme
description: Jason Servis, the highest-profile defendant among more than two dozen people charged after a sprawling F.B.I. investigation, pleaded guilty to two counts related to the use of banned substances.
content: The former thoroughbred trainer Jason Servis was sentenced on Wednesday to four years in federal prison after pleading guilty to participating in what prosecutors called a far-reaching doping scheme meant to improve the performance of his horses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Soft Landing Optimism Is Everywhere. That’s Happened Before.
description: People are often sure that the economy is going to settle down gently right before it plunges into recession, a reason for caution and humility.
content: In late 1989, an economic commentary newsletter from the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland asked the question that was on everyone’s mind after a series of Federal Reserve rate increases: “How Soft a Landing?” Analysts were pretty sure growth was going to cool gently and without a painful downturn — the question was how gently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Rufo
title: D.E.I. Programs Are Getting in the Way of Liberal Education
description: Highly ideological D.E.I. programs erode the environment of open, substantive debate that is the basic prerequisite for liberal education.
content: Academia is in the midst of a generational turmoil. Blue states such as California and Oregon have recently transformed their public universities with expansive “diversity, equity and inclusion” programs that have profound implications for admissions, speech, hiring and scholarship. Red states such as Florida and Texas have recently passed legislation abolishing them, concluding that the programs that have sprung up to execute D.E.I. promote a stifling orthodoxy that undermines the pursuit of truth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Zwirner Pivots on Plans for New Chelsea Gallery
description: Because of financial problems the project’s developer encountered during the pandemic, the gallerist is abandoning a 21st Street development and pursuing another building project.
content: Citing a developer’s “financial headwinds during Covid,” the art dealer David Zwirner said he has decided not to proceed with a 50,000-square foot, five-story, $50 million gallery designed by Renzo Piano on a corner lot at 540 West 21st Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: A Self-Portrait of the Roma, Without the Stereotypes
description: The exhibition “Barvalo” is billed as the first show of its kind to combine contributions from multiple Romani artists and curators. They are sharing their culture on their own terms.
content: When Gabi Jimenez, a French Spanish Romani painter, first heard several years ago that a major museum in France was planning an exhibition on Romani culture and history, he said he thought it would be “a mess.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Researchers Poke Holes in Safety Controls of ChatGPT and Other Chatbots
description: A new report indicates that the guardrails for widely used chatbots can be thwarted, leading to an increasingly unpredictable environment for the technology.
content: When artificial intelligence companies build online chatbots, like ChatGPT, Claude and Google Bard, they spend months adding guardrails that are supposed to prevent their systems from generating hate speech, disinformation and other toxic material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: The Life and Death of a ‘Punk Rock Warhol’
description: Frank Kozik made his name with his playfully gruesome concert posters for Nirvana, Soundgarden and Butthole Surfers. He added to his underground fame with his boundary-pushing “art toys.”
content: Last month at the Columbarium funeral home in San Francisco, mourners gathered for the artist Frank Kozik, who died recently at 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Wordle Hints
description: What should be allowed to keep your solving streak alive?
content: Liz writes: My husband and I are daily Wordle players. I currently have a solving streak of 145. If I get to the final guess, I’ll Google hints of the day for an assist. My husband objects to this practice. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

description: Step-by-step instructions for creating your own fantastical headpieces.

description: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

content: The glamorous “Sailing Capital of the World” on Rhode Island offers plenty of rewards beyond the yachts and Gilded Age mansions.

description: The 13.8-foot statue, unveiled in Dabu-dong, Gyeongsangbuk-do, South Korea, honors former President Truman on the 70th anniversary of the Korean War armistice.
